_header: Every manner creature / Disposed unto gentilesse
_description: John Lydgate, A Lover’s Lament — fifteen 8-line stanzas (ababbcbc) each ending, ‘ladye dere’ and envoy

BodAsh59.First Lines:
Every maner creaturedisposed vn to gentylesseBooþe of
                    kynde and of natureHaþe in his hert moste
                    gladnesse…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…þat of mercy shee not disdeyneTo bee my souereine ladye
                    dere
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here folowþe nexst a compleynte made by Lydegate for þe departing
                    of Thomas Chaucier in to fraunce by hes servauntz vpon þe kynges ambassate
                    (f. 45v)
BodAsh59.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             “Rev. ed. of G. H. Kingsley,  Francis Thynne:
                    Animadversions upon Chaucer’s Works” 
             EETS
         o.s. 9 (1865), repr. 1965; re-issued Chaucer Society 2nd ser. 13
            (1876): 122-6.

BLAdd16165.First Lines: Euery maner creatureDisposed vn to gentyllesse…
BLAdd16165.Last Lines:
…þat she of mercy not disdeyneTo be my soueraine lady
                    dere
BLAdd16165.Attributed Title:
Amerous balade by Lydegate made at departing of Thomas Chaucieres on
                    þe kynges ambassade in to ffraunce (f. 249v)

Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.

                        ed.

EETS

BLHar367.Last Lines:
…that of marcy she not disdeyneto be my sovereyn lady
                    dere
BLHar367.Note:
Written by the hand of John Stow, on a separate leaf tipped into the
                    volume, once folded across the middle.
BLHar367.Attributed Title:
here folowithe a complaynt made by lidgate for the departyng of Thomas
                    Chawcer into fraunce by his servante vpon the kyngs ambassate (f. 87)
